docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN injuries happen on trips in the wild, or even on casual outdoor vacations, a case can sometimes be made for blaming the victim. Failing to wear a helmet on a bike, skipping vaccinations before going camping, jumping off a boat in the middle of a lake: Such actions, or inactions, are invitations to danger. While eco-tourism and adventure travel in remote parts of the world have grown exponentially in the last decade, safety is also a serious concern on familiar ground.
docs.abstract: Betsy Wade Practical Traveler column offers safety suggestions and medical precautions in light of rising popularity of eco-tourism and adventure travel; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SHIRLEY FORMAN has always resisted going to the doctor. ''I don't believe I've seen a doctor more than 6 times in the last 10 years,'' said Mrs. Forman, 77, who lives in Hartsdale. ''And those six visits were the result of an automobile accident.'' Mrs. Forman said she finally gave in to the pressures of her family to go for a physical examination when she saw an advertisement for Women Caring for Women, an all-female medical practice in Ardsley, the only comprehensive health center for women under one roof in the county.

headline.main: Female Doctors Limit Practice to Women

docs.abstract: Article on Women Caring for Women, all-female medical practice in Ardsley, NY, that offers fully comprehensive health care services; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: YOU'D love to shoot the moon with your mutual fund, slapping your money down on the wildest bet you can find. But, of course, you're worried that you could lose your whole nest egg. If that describes your outlook, a handful of the nation's biggest insurers have got a deal for you. Well, maybe.

headline.main: Life Insurance, of Sorts, for Mutual Funds

docs.lead_paragraph: Just about everyone on Capitol Hill professes interest in producing legislation that protects patients from unfair health insurance practices. But the prospect of actually passing meaningful protections, as opposed to talking about it, is uncertain. President Clinton tried to whip up support for Democratic proposals yesterday, but the Republicans are balking at Democratic plans as too burdensome on the managed-care industry. Yet it is the Democratic proposals that more fully reflect the recommendations of a Presidential advisory commission to improve health plan quality. The Senate Republican bill, S. 326, sponsored by James Jeffords of Vermont, is too limited to accomplish that purpose. The bill, which was approved by the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee on a straight party-line vote of 10 to 8, contains some consumer protections. It includes provisions that require health plans to pay for emergency-room care if a prudent person has reason to believe an emergency exists, allow patients to go directly to gynecologists and pediatricians, and safeguard medical privacy. But it is unacceptable because most of its provisions would apply only to 48 million individuals covered by plans in which large employers act as their own insurers, leaving 110 million people in other plans unprotected.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Republicans on Capital Hill are balking at Democratic plans for patients'rights bill as too burdensome on managed-care industry; notes Democratic proposals more fully reflect recommendations of Presidential advisory commission to improve health plan quality; says insurance lobby seeks to defeat any new regulations as too costly, but Congressional Budget Office has estimated that consumer protections under Democratic plan would increase health plan costs by only 2.8 percent

docs.lead_paragraph: A glazier who spends his days clinging to the sides of skyscrapers, Dan McGough doesn't really believe in goblins, poltergeists or jinxed job sites. But every day, before he reports to work at the accident-plagued Conde Nast building in Times Square, Mr. McGough, 30, crosses himself and mutters a little prayer. ''I'm not a superstitious guy, but there's definitely something wrong with this job,'' he said, as he stood beneath the nearly completed tower, the scene of a small, smoky fire on Wednesday that drew more than 120 firefighters, herds of thrill-hungry tourists and a jumble of television cameras. ''I've seen more problems here than in all the other jobs I've done in 10 years put together.''

headline.main: Invisible Tenant in New Tower?; Some Say Times Square's Conde Nast Building Is Jinxed

docs.abstract: Several construction accidents, including small, smoky fire this week, at new Conde Nast Building that is rising in Times Square prompts some observers to suggest building is jinxed, notion that it disputed by real-estate and construction professionals; industry experts say that considering inherent danger of erecting skyscrapers in most densely populated parts of one of world's most densely populated cities, accidents are remarkably low; photos depict several of accidents at Conde Nast building, including last July's scaffold collapse, killing one person (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With Congress reconvening next week, President Clinton flew here today to try to whip up public enthusiasm for the Democratic proposal to establish a ''patient's bill of rights.'' Mr. Clinton told a group of about 400 union workers and health care providers that he had advocated the patients program until he was ''blue in the face,'' but he wanted the public to express its support by signing a petition on the Internet to counter the opposition of large health maintenance organizations and insurance companies.

headline.main: Clinton Urges Petition Drive to Pass Health Plan

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton addresses group of health care providers in Philadelphia, Pa, as he tries to whip up public enthusiasm for Democratic proposal to establish 'patient's bill of rights'; calls on public to sign petition on Internet to counter opposition of large health maintenance organizations and insurance companies; says Republican-controlled Congress will not feel any pressure to act on matter unless there is clear demand from public; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of the Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the nation's No. 2 hospital chain, rose 21.2 percent today after it told investors its operations were improving despite a drop in its fiscal third-quarter profit. The company said net income fell 16 percent, to $124 million, or 40 cents a diluted share, in the quarter ended Feb. 28, compared with $148 million, or 47 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Tenet was expected to earn 43 cents, the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings.

headline.main: Tenet Healthcare Stock Up 21% Despite Drop in Quarterly Profit

docs.abstract: Shares of Tenet Healthcare Corp rise 21.2 percent after it tells investigators its operations are improving despite drop in its fiscal third-quarter profit; says net income fell 16 percent, to $124 million in quarter ended Feb 28, compared with $148 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 9 percent, to $2.8 billion from $2.56 billion; Tenet says its turnaround plan for eight bankrupt hospitals in Philadelphia area acquired last year is ahead of schedule (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Erica Aguilar, a Mexican-American born in Denver, is 21 years old and has three children, ages 4, 2 and 8 months. The children have Medicaid, and for them she uses the city's La Casa Family Health Center. But Ms. Aguilar herself has no health insurance. She works 26 hours a week as a sales clerk at Montgomery Ward for $6.50 an hour, and as a part timer, she is ineligible for insurance even if she could pay her share of the premium. Yet she earns too much to get Medicaid.

headline.main: Denver's Hispanic Residents Point to Ills of the Uninsured

docs.abstract: Situation confronting many of Denver's Hispanic population--lack of health insurance--is seen emblematic of striking disparity in nation's health care system; for reasons that are largely economic, but also cultural, 34 percent of nation's 31 million Hispanic people have no health insurance, compared with 22 percent of blacks and 12 percent of non-Hispanic whites; over all, 43 million people in nation lack health insurance, up from 31 million decade ago; while Hispanic people appear to be gaining in economic and political strength, they disporportionately lack insurance coverage and access to professional care; that is particularly true for the three-quarters who are from Mexico and Central America; Denver has vast Hispanic population, making up quarter of city's half-million residents, compared with 11 percent nationwide; Hispanic residents are mostly young and mostly from Mexico and Central Ameria, and as in many cities their lack of professional health care sustains thriving system of alternative care built on religion, tradition and home remedies; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Resurrecting concerns about whether managed care companies do much real managing, starting with their own businesses, Humana Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit would come in well below forecasts. The company said its operating profit would be 20 to 24 cents a share in the quarter, down 30 percent from earlier projections. Additionally, the company will take a $90 million charge for a renegotiated contract with Florida hospitals and reserves to cover future costs, which will probably lead to a net loss for the quarter.

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Humana Finds That the Going Gets Tougher

docs.abstract: Market Place column on Humana Inc's warning that first-quarter profit will come in well below forecasts; says warning comes because underlying cost of care in hospitals and doctors' offices are rising faster than expected, faster even than double-digit percentile increases in premiums that Humana charged its customers this year; holds expenses are climbing even faster than premiums as patients use more medical services and managed care companies encounter growing resistance to cutbacks on payments (M)
